title: CBI calls for more skilled migrants to get visas

Fri, Jul 17, 2015, 06:25 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 35 mins CBI calls for more skilled migrants to get visas By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 9 minutes ago Print 
Business group said a number of large companies have been stuck without candidates after the UK hit the quota on tier two visas 
Businesses are unable to fill vacant jobs because of a cap on certain work visas that has now been reached two months in a row, as an increasingly tight migration policy blocks skilled workers from reaching UK firms, according to the CBI business lobby group. 
John Cridland, director general at the CBI, said the cap on tier two general visas for skilled workers at 20,700 per year was exacerbating the skills shortage across British firms, which he described as “the Achilles’ heel of our productivity performance”. 
He said about 20 large companies had already complained to the CBI that they were unable to fill roles as their candidates from outside the European Economic Area were caught up in a glut of unsuccessful visa applicants, who can reapply the following month if they are rejected. 
The monthly quota was reached in June and July, which the CBI said was also a symptom of a recovering economy that has spurred growth in demand for labour. Firms must demonstrate that they cannot fill a post with a British-based worker before they can sponsor an application for this visa. 
“I understand the need of government to tackle public concerns about migration but I don’t think they are concerned about skilled migrants or students,” he said, referring to the Home Office plans to limit international students working during or after their studies. 
The CBI's John Cridland said the Government was in a cul-de-sac on migration targets 
The current cap on skilled migrants “worked during the recession" but wouldn’t be appropriate now, added deputy director general Katja Hall, although the CBI has not suggested how much the cap should be raised. 
Last month, the Government asked the Migration Advisory Committee to report back this year on the effects of restricting tier two visas further, only allowing non-EEA candidates into the country if they are relevant to “genuine skills shortages and highly specialist experts”. 
According to the Home Office, there was a 13pc rise in tier two visa applications to 93,067 in the year to March., which includes the general visas included in the cap as well as visas for inter-company transfers, sportspeople and ministers of religion. Four-fifths of the applications came from the US, India, Australia, China and Japan. 
Mr Cridland said the Conservatives "need to back out of the cul-de-sac they are in" on the net migration target of less than 100,000 people a year, suggesting that gross migration was a more useful measure of visa policies. 
He also said that the new living wage is “a gamble” that could see firms reduce working hours to offset the additional cost. “The CBI supports a higher skilled, higher wage economy, but legislating for a living wage does not reflect businesses’ ability to pay, especially small firms." * David Cameron will never hit his net migration target - here's why
